title: Benchmark: The Simple Mediation Model with Missing Data using semmcci vs. Nonparametric Bootstrap in lavaan
code: n <- 1000 a <- 0.50 b <- 0.50 cp <- 0.25 s2_em <- 1 - a^2 s2_ey <- 1 - cp^2 - a^2 * b^2 - b^2 * s2_em - 2 * cp * a * b em <- rnorm(n = n, mean = 0, sd = sqrt(s2_em)) ey <- rnorm(n = n, mean = 0, sd = sqrt(s2_ey)) X <- rnorm(n = n) M <- a * X + em Y <- cp * X + b * M + ey df <- data.frame(X, M, Y)  # Create data set with missing values.  miss <- sample(1:dim(df)[1], 300) df[miss[1:100], "X"] <- NA df[miss[101:200], "M"] <- NA df[miss[201:300], "Y"] <- NA

title: Benchmark: The Simple Mediation Model with Missing Data using semmcci vs. Nonparametric Bootstrap in lavaan
text: indirect effect defined product slopes paths X M labeled M Y labeled b. example, interested confidence intervals indirect defined product b using := operator lavaan model syntax.
code: model <- "   Y ~ cp * X + b * M   M ~ a * X   indirect := a * b   direct := cp   total := cp + (a * b) "

title: Benchmark: The Simple Mediation Model with Missing Data using semmcci vs. Nonparametric Bootstrap in lavaan
text: can now fit model using sem() function lavaan. using missing = "fiml" handle missing data lavaan. Since missing values x, also set fixed.x = FALSE.
code: fit <- sem(data = df, model = model, missing = "fiml", fixed.x = FALSE)

what: Summary of Benchmark Results Relative to the Fastest Method
title: Benchmark
Benchmark
text: MC approaches faster compared NB counterparts. Note increasing model complexity increase computational cost NB. However, MC, model complexity increase computational cost simulation stage. example, MI estimates computationally intensive ML estimates. results large difference NBML two NB methods using MI, , NBMI MINB. Note MINB faster NBMI expected still significantly slower MC approaches. However, perform model fitting step outside benchmark calculation, speed MCML MCMI virtually identical. implementation, however, MCMI little bit slower MCML generates two sets confidence intervals (vcov vcov_tilde) MCML generates single set. Since MC relies single estimate parameters sampling covariance matrix, suited complex models. NOTE: Note since NB needs point estimates, closed form solution indirect effect used NBMI MINB. optimization used estimate parameters context structural equation modeling, NBMI MINB significantly slower.

title: Data Generation
text: Mplus Version 8.8 Demo GNU/Linux used study. Note version equivalent commercial release except limitations number variables can used analysis. See https://www.statmodel.com/demo.shtml details limitations installation instructions. functions package work versions Mplus various platforms. However, compatibility, recommend use Mplus Version 8.8 Demo GNU/Linux. functions package require user specify path Mplus binary argument mplus_bin. example, default location Mplus demo binary GNU/Linux /opt/mplusdemo/mpdemo. title: Mplus
code: DATA:         FILE = data.dat; VARIABLE:         NAMES = X M Y;         USEVARIABLES = X M Y;         MISSING = ALL (-999); ANALYSIS:         TYPE = GENERAL;         ESTIMATOR = ML; MODEL:         Y ON X;         Y ON M (B);         M ON X (A);         X WITH X; SAVEDATA:         RESULTS ARE results.out;         TECH3 IS tech3.out;

title: Mplus
code: DATA:         FILE = data.dat; VARIABLE:         NAMES = X M Y;         USEVARIABLES = X M Y;         MISSING = ALL (-999); ANALYSIS:         TYPE = GENERAL;         ESTIMATOR = ML;         BOOTSTRAP = 5000; MODEL:         Y ON X;         Y ON M (B);         M ON X (A);         X WITH X; MODEL CONSTRAINT:         NEW(AB);         AB = A*B; OUTPUT:         CINT(bootstrap);   ! percentile       ! CINT(bcbootstrap); ! bias-corrected

title: Monte Carlo Method using Open-Source Software
code: mu <- c(   0.872,   0.745 ) varnames <- c("alpha", "beta") names(mu) <- varnames mu #> alpha  beta  #> 0.872 0.745

title: Monte Carlo Method using Open-Source Software
text: parameter estimates interest \(\hat{\alpha} = 0.872\) \(\hat{\beta} = 0.745\) corresponding sampling covariance matrix.
code: Sigma <- matrix(   data = c(     1.253778e-02,     5.244734e-06,     5.244734e-06,     1.429014e-02   ),   nrow = 2 ) rownames(Sigma) <- colnames(Sigma) <- varnames Sigma #>              alpha         beta #> alpha 1.253778e-02 5.244734e-06 #> beta  5.244734e-06 1.429014e-02

title: Monte Carlo Method using Open-Source Software
text: simulation stage, \(\hat{\alpha}\) \(\hat{\beta}\) used mean vector \(\mu\). covariance matrix \(\Sigma\) consists corresponding sampling covariance matrix.

title: Monte Carlo Method using Open-Source Software
text: MASS package can used R generate sampling distribution indirect effect.
code: library(MASS) mustar <- mvrnorm(   n = 20000,   mu = mu,   Sigma = Sigma ) ab <- mustar[, 1] * mustar[, 2]

text: number rows missing values divided total number rows. value prop argument AmputeData() wrapper around mice::ampute() function.
code: sum_row <- sum(!complete.cases(data_missing)) prop_row <- sum_row / n c(   sum_row = sum_row,   prop_row = prop_row ) #>  sum_row prop_row  #>  276.000    0.276

what: Proportion of missing values by column
title: Proportion of Missing Values
text: number rows per column missing values divided total number rows.
code: sum_col <- colSums(is.na(data_missing)) names(sum_col) <- paste0(   "sum_col_",   names(sum_col) ) prop_col <- sum_col / n names(prop_col) <- gsub("sum", "prop", names(sum_col)) c(   sum_col,   prop_col ) #>  sum_col_x  sum_col_m  sum_col_y prop_col_x prop_col_m prop_col_y  #>    141.000    135.000    146.000      0.141      0.135      0.146

what: Proportion of missing values by cell
title: Proportion of Missing Values
text: number cells missing values divided number rows times number columns.
code: sum_cell <- sum(is.na(data_missing)) prop_cell <- sum_cell / (n * 3) prop_cell #> [1] 0.1406667 c(   sum_cell = sum_cell,   prop_cell = prop_cell ) #>    sum_cell   prop_cell  #> 422.0000000   0.1406667

title: Proportion of Missing Values
text: simple simulation show empirical proportions combination sample size n prop used study 5000 replications.

title: Proportion of Missing Values
code: bar <- function(mech) {   foo <- function(x,                   reps = 5000,                   mech,                   seed = 42) {     set.seed(42)     n <- x[1]     prop <- x[2]     data_complete <- GenData(n = n)     colMeans(       do.call(         what = "rbind",         args = lapply(           X = 1:reps,           FUN = function(i, mech) {             data_missing <- AmputeData(               data_complete,               mech = mech,               prop = prop             )             sum_row <- sum(!complete.cases(data_missing))             prop_row <- sum_row / n             row <- c(               sum_row = sum_row,               prop_row = prop_row             )             sum_col <- colSums(is.na(data_missing))             names(sum_col) <- paste0(               "sum_col_",               names(sum_col)             )             prop_col <- sum_col / n             names(prop_col) <- gsub("sum", "prop", names(sum_col))             col <- c(               sum_col,               prop_col             )             sum_cell <- sum(is.na(data_missing))             prop_cell <- sum_cell / (n * 3)             prop_cell             cell <- c(               sum_cell = sum_cell,               prop_cell = prop_cell             )             c(               n = n,               prop = prop,               row,               col,               cell,               reps = reps             )           },           mech = mech         )       )     )   }   do.call(     what = "rbind",     args = lapply(       X = as.data.frame(         t(           expand.grid(             n = unique(manMCMedMiss::params$n),             prop = 1:3 * .10           )         )       ),       FUN = foo,       mech = mech     )   ) } prop_mar <- bar("MAR") prop_mcar <- bar("MCAR")

text: results Data frame. package data frame results(). type Character string. Type results plot. Proportion missing data. Valid values .1, .2, .3. Note mech = "COMPLETE", prop set 0. n Vector positive integers. Sample size. Valid values 50, 75, 100, 150, 200, 250, 500, 1000. n = NULL, use sample sizes.

title: Fit the Simple Mediation Model using Multiple Imputation — FitModelMI
text: Returns list following elements: coef Vector pooled coefficients/parameter estimates \(\bar{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\). vcov Total covariance matrix \(\mathbf{V}_{\mathrm{total}}\). vcov_tilde Adjusted total covariance matrix \(\tilde{\mathbf{V}}_{\mathrm{total}}\). vcov_between Covariance imputations \(\mathbf{V}_{\mathrm{}}\). vcov_within Covariance within imputations \(\mathbf{V}_{\mathrm{within}}\). ariv Average relative increase variance \(\mathrm{ARIV}\). m Number imputations \(M\). k Number parameters \(k\). nu1 Numerator degrees freedom \(\nu_1\) \(D_1\). nu2 Denominator degrees freedom \(\nu_2\) \(D_1\). d1 \(D_1\) test statistic.

title: Fit the Simple Mediation Model using Multiple Imputation — FitModelMI
text: Let $$M = \textrm{Number imputations}, \quad \textrm{}$$ $$m = \left\{ 1, 2, \cdots, M \right\}.$$ vector pooled coefficients/parameter estimates given $$     \bar{\boldsymbol{\theta}}     =     M^{-1}     \sum_{m = 1}^{M}     \hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{m} . $$ covariance within imputations given $$     \mathbf{V}_{\mathrm{within}}     =     M^{-1}     \sum_{m = 1}^{M}     \mathrm{Var}     \left(     \hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{m}     \right) $$ \(\mathrm{Var} \left( \hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{m} \right)\) parameter covariance matrix \(m^{\mathrm{th}}\) imputation. covariance imputations given $$     \mathbf{V}_{\mathrm{}}     =     \left(     M - 1     \right)^{-1}     \sum_{m = 1}^{M}     \left(     \hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{m}     -     \bar{\boldsymbol{\theta}}     \right)     \left(     \hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{m}     -     \bar{\boldsymbol{\theta}}     \right)^{\prime} . $$ total covariance matrix given $$     \mathbf{V}_{\mathrm{total}}     =     \mathbf{V}_{\mathrm{within}}     +     \mathbf{V}_{\mathrm{}}     +     M^{-1}     \mathbf{V}_{\mathrm{}} . $$ adjusted total covariance matrix given $$     \tilde{\mathbf{V}}_{\mathrm{total}}     =     \left(     1     +     \mathrm{ARIV}     \right)     \mathbf{V}_{\mathrm{within}} $$ $$     \mathrm{ARIV}     =     k^{-1}     \left[     \left(     1     +     M^{-1}     \right)     \mathrm{tr}     \left(     \mathbf{V}_{\mathrm{}}     \mathbf{V}_{\mathrm{within}}^{-1}     \right)     \right] $$ \(k\) number parameters.

title: Fit the Simple Mediation Model using Multiple Imputation — FitModelMI
text: Li, K. H., Raghunathan, T. E., & Rubin, D. B. (1991). Large-sample significance levels multiply imputed data using moment-based statistics F reference distribution. Journal American Statistical Association, 86 (416), 1065–1073. doi:10.1080/01621459.1991.10475152 Rubin, D. B. (1987). Multiple imputation nonresponse surveys. John Wiley & Sons, Inc. doi:10.1002/9780470316696

Values fit. free_parameters Number free parameters h0_loglikelihood H0 loglikelihood. h1_loglikelihood H1 loglikelihood. aic Akaike information criterion (AIC). bic Bayesian information criterion (BIC). sabic Sample-size adjusted BIC (SABIC). chisq Chi-square value. chisq_df Chi-square degrees freedom. chisq_p Chi-square p-value. cfi Comparative fit index (CFI). tli Tucker–Lewis index (TLI). rmsea Root mean square error approximation (RMSEA) estimate. rmsea_low Root mean square error approximation (RMSEA) lower limit confidence interval. rmsea_up Root mean square error approximation (RMSEA) upper limit confidence interval. rmsea_p Root mean square error approximation (RMSEA) probability. srmr Standardized root mean square residual (SRMR). condition_number Condition number information matrix (ratio smallest largest eigenvalue).

title: Fit the Simple Mediation Model using Normal Theory Maximum Likelihood — FitModelML
Generate Data — GenData
text: Let simple mediation model defined equations $$Y = \delta_{Y} + \tau^{\prime} X + \beta M + \varepsilon_{Y},$$ $$M = \delta_{M} + \alpha X + \varepsilon_{M}.$$ function generates data multivariate normal distribution using model-implied mean vector covariance matrix simple mediation model. See MASS::mvrnorm() details.

title: Generate Data — GenData
code: GenData(n = 100L, tauprime = 0, beta = 0.5, alpha = 0.5, mu = 0, sigmasq = 1)

title: Generate Data — GenData
text: n Positive integer. Sample size. tauprime Numeric. \(\tau^{\prime}\), , slope \(Y\) regressed \(X\), adjusting \(M\). beta Numeric. \(\beta\), , slope \(Y\) regressed \(M\), adjusting \(X\). alpha Numeric vector. Significance level. mu Numeric. Common mean \(X\), \(M\), \(Y\), , \(\mu_{X} = \mu_{M} = \mu_{Y}\). sigmasq Numeric. Common variance \(X\), \(M\), \(Y\), , \(\sigma^{2}_{X} = \sigma^{2}_{M} = \sigma^{2}_{Y}\).

MC.FIML Monte Carlo method full information maximum likelihood estimates. MC.MI Monte Carlo method multiple imputation estimates. MC.MI.ADJ Monte Carlo method adjusted multiple imputation estimates. NBBC.COMPLETE bias-corrected nonparametric bootstrap maximum likelihood estimates complete data. NBBC.FIML full maximum likelihood nested within bias-corrected nonparametric bootstrap. NBPC.COMPLETE percentile nonparametric bootstrap full maximum likelihood estimates complete. NBPC.FIML full maximum likelihood nested within percentile nonparametric bootstrap. SIG.COMPLETE joint-significant test complete data. SIG.FIML joint-significant test full maximum likelihood estimates. SIG.MI joint-significant test multiple imputation estimates. SIG.MI.ADJ joint-significant test adjusted multiple imputation estimates.
